question: Should the niqab and other face coverings in schools be banned?

content.source_1: European Court of Human Rights, S.A.S. v. France (Application no. 43835/11), Grand Chamber judgment, 1 July 2014 — Upheld France’s general ban on face coverings in public spaces as compatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, accepting “living together” and public-order aims; cited by proponents as legal support that such bans (including in schools) can be lawful.
content.source_2: Corey, R.M., Jones, U., & Singer, A.C. (2020). Acoustic effects of face masks on speech. The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 148(4), 2371–2375; and Ruba, A.L., & Pollak, S.D. (2020). Children’s emotion inferences from masked faces. PLOS ONE, 15(12): e0243708 — Peer‑reviewed findings that face coverings attenuate high‑frequency speech cues (reducing intelligibility) and impair children’s emotion recognition, respectively; used to argue that face coverings hinder classroom communication and social‑emotional learning.
content.source_3: UN Human Rights Committee, Views adopted 17 July 2018, Communications Nos. 2747/2016 (Yaker v. France) and 2807/2016 (Hebbadj v. France) — Found that France’s blanket ban on full‑face veils violated Articles 18 and 26 of the ICCPR (freedom of religion and non‑discrimination), rejecting “living together” as a proportionate justification; cited by opponents as evidence that blanket bans breach international human rights standards.
content.source_4: Open Society Foundations, Unveiling the Truth: Why 32 Muslim Women Wear the Full‑Face Veil in France, Belgium, and the Netherlands (2011) and After the Ban: Experiences of 10 Women in France (2013) — Qualitative reports documenting that bans led some women to withdraw from education, employment, and public life, increasing isolation; used to argue bans harm inclusion and access to schooling without achieving stated aims.
content.source_5: Equality and Human Rights Commission (UK), Religion or belief: A guide to the law for schools (2014) — Advises schools to adopt proportionate, non‑discriminatory uniform and appearance policies that consider religious dress and allow reasonable accommodations; supports the view that case‑by‑case solutions are preferable to blanket bans.
content.source_6: Netherlands, Wet gedeeltelijk verbod gezichtsbedekkende kleding (Partial Ban on Face‑Covering Clothing), Stb. 2018, 238; in force 1 August 2019 — Statutory ban on face coverings in specified public‑sector settings including educational institutions, with fines for non‑compliance; presented by supporters as a practical policy model placing schools within the scope of a face‑covering prohibition.
